review_title: Super Bright Tiny Light, but it's not waterproof
reviews:
I always carry two lights - a big one for daily use and a tiny one as a backup. You never know when your big light will fail. So I was very pleased that Nitecore put together this minuscule half-ounce powerhouse of a flashlight. It's good enough to use as a daily light while being only half the size of a Bic lighter.

The 380 lumen turbo mode is activated as long as you hold the top button. Three other well-spaced light levels are available by holding the bottom button for 2 seconds. You switch between the levels by tapping the top button. The light remembers the level between activations, so if you turn it off on low, it turns on in low. The lowest light level is more than enough to read by, and with 2-1/2 days of run-time it's like the Energizer bunny. If you tap the top button while the light is off, it flashes the battery level - once for +25%, twice for +50%, and three times for +75%.

The beam pattern gives a smooth 170-degree flood pattern with an evenly bright spot about one foot wide at 3-feet. It has a nice linear fall off from there and no color fringes. The light color of the CW version is essentially the same as a standard florescent lamp.

I gave it 5 stars, but there are a two negatives. It has turned on in my pocket several times. I have to leave it in demo mode, which automatically turns off the light after 30 seconds. At least it's easy to shift to normal mode by pressing both buttons for two seconds, but I wish Nitecore would change the turn on behavior. Instead of having to press the ON button for two seconds, make it three quick presses in less than a second. That should stop accidental activation and significantly speed up the turn-on time.

The second reason is that this light is only water resistant, not waterproof, which means if you fall in the pool with it, it's probably not going to end well for the light. If my cell phone can be waterproof, I don't know why this little light can't pull off the same feat. Now everything in my daily carry is waterproof, so this light can't be the exception. I keep it in a waterproof sleeve I made from two pieces of heat-shrink tubing.

If you are looking for an unobtrusive backup light for your everyday carry, this is a great candidate for it's price, size, and performance. If the folks at Nitecore keep innovating like this, I will keep buying their products.

review_title: Wonderful light but fatal operational flaw. Not for me.
reviews: I have carried the Nitecore TIP for a long time and consider it one of the BEST small lights available. I thought I would also try the smaller TINI 360, and ordered two - one for myself and one for a gift. Well. As for the performance of this little light, it is superb after you get used to holding the "ON' button down for a few seconds before the light actually illuminates. The levels of brightness and the internal battery life make this an exceptionally nice piece of gear. HOWEVER- it will never be an EDC for me. REASON- the two very very tiny buttons which control on/off and brightness levels, are so close together that it is all too easy to hit both at once, without even realizing it. Why does this matter? Well- if you hit both at once, the light goes into a 'demo mode'- which means that after 30 seconds, the light goes off. Dark. Not good. Now, it IS easy to get it back to the operational mode by holding both buttons down until the light flashes twice. THEN you can use it as you intended to. I am not certain why this feature was built in, and I know of no way to disable it - which would be great! But as it is, if youa re in any critical situation - working under the hood of a car at night looking for a leak, walking through a totally dark house, whatever - having the light unexpectedly turn off, then having to have the presence of mind to hold both buttons down and wait for the two flashes, then pressing the on button and waiting those few more seconds for it to light- it is nust not something I am comfortable relying on. So if, knowing these details, you opt for this little micro-light, go for it. For me, I am staying with the slightly larger but utterly dependable TIP.

review_title: My favorite flashlight. Insanely bright, insanely small, great battery life, mildly annoying button
reviews:
This is a superb keychain light. It is super small, you won't even notice it in your pocket. It gets insanely bright on turbo mode and very bright on high. The battery holds a charge for a long time and seems to last forever on medium/low brightness which I find I use the most. USB charging is very convenient, I last charged mine over 3 weeks ago, have used it occasionally, and its still reporting 75+% charge.

Low brightness is perfect for a dark room at night or as I used it to navigate a dark room to avoid waking a sleeping baby! Medium brightness is perfect for any nighttime situation and is in the range of what most people would think of as "a normal bright flashlight". High brightness is really bright, great for finding dropped objects in dim locations even on bright days. Turbo mode is insane for a flashlight of this size, it is blinding even indoors during the day with the lights on. The performance given the size will wow people. It performs like a light 10x its size.

The light remembers its previous brightness when you turn it off and on. It will tell you its battery charge in 25% increments by blinking the LEDs when you press the mode button. You can only use turbo brightness by holding the button, I assume because otherwise it would overheat or run down the physically small battery too quickly. It has an auto-off (30s) demo mode which seems kinda useless but is easily turned off by pressing both buttons after which it can be forgotten about.

I have not tested water resistance but it does not seem likely that it is too water resistant. I think it would survive some splashes and rain, maybe a quick dunk, but probably not a soaking.

The only downside is the slightly annoying power button. They put it on a delay to avoid it being activated in your pocket and draining the batteries. The issue is the delay is a bit on the long size, ~2.5 seconds, and it feels annoying to pull out the light and wait for it to turn on compared to most lights which activate instantly. In practice I find this isn't as much of an issue as other reviewers make it out to be but it may be a big issue for some.

Overall I highly recommend the Nitecore Tini. It's my favorite flashlight and the one I use the most because its so small I always have it on me.

reviews:
I've worn many lights under my shirt since the Blackout of 2003, when a nearly dead Princeton Tec Pulsar light lit up a pitch-black sidewalk NYC that night. Various LRI Photons (including a REX), a Fenix E05, a FourSevens Atom A0, and most recently, a few Nitecore TUBES. And now the Nitecore TINI.

Three nicely spaced levels, from "middle of the night in hotel room" low, to "I know it fell on the floor here, somewhere" medium, to "nope, not a bad guy behind that tree, just a shadow" high. And there's the "day for night" turbo, which used to required a double CR123A light just a few years ago.

The light is shelled in lightweight aluminum, which increases durability. The weight penalty is worth it. The bezel, however, is plastic, but worse, it causes light spillback, which is distracting.

The rear-most button turns the light off/on, but it has to be held down for 1/2 seconds before activating the LED. The front-most button cycles thru the three levels. From off, the front button turns on turbo mode, almost instantly--no 1/2 second delay.

There is a last-on-first on mode memory, and no way around this, so you do have to prepare for high when you're expecting low. Normally, the light will turn off after 30 seconds, but this is switchable by holding down both buttons.

This light uses a Cree XP-G2 S3 emitter, which has a nice pure-white tint. It's by no means a high CRI or even a neutral tint emitter, but better than a typical 5mm "white" LED.

USB recharging is expected nowadays, and the TINI takes about 2.5 hours to fill up from empty, The little rubber plug is a bit flimsy and will probably fall off one day. The blinking while charging is welcome.

I used it a lot over four days including a weekend, and finally had to recharge it. When the battery voltage drops, first turbo is lost (the blue lights will blink as a reminder), then eventually, high is lost. After that, the light wouldn't turn on, so I don't know if medium and low were lost at some point. I'm satisfied with the runtime.

I mounted the TINI in a Nitecore headlamp strap (the one with different elastic straps to accommodate different positions), and it worked perfectly. There may be other options for mounting this light to other objects, including maybe adding a velcro dot to the large smooth side of the light.

Took off one star for the light spillback, and the 1/2 second delay when turning on.

After losing my Nitecore TIP, I thought it was a good time to upgrade. The TINI is significantly smaller, and somewhat brighter. As soon as I got the copper version, I was disappointed. It's a pretty good keychain flashlight, but it is far from perfect, and I'd rather have the bigger TIP model. The TINI has some flaws that are worth noting:

1) It takes a long press to turn on. It takes about two seconds to turn on. On paper, two seconds sound like nothing; in practice, they feel eternal. It is very annoying.

2) It doesn't have a lockout mode. I personally don't mind this, but a) a lot of people do and b) the long press seems to be a safeguard because there is no lockout mode. Having a lockout mode and instant on would satisfy pretty much everybody.

3) It pooped out on me after six months. I didn't use it that much, maybe two to three times a week. I normally use my pocket flashlight because it's easier for me to deploy. Still, it didn't last. I'm not saying they're all the same, but from the beginning, the build quality felt bad and then that happened. I repeat: it's worth noting.

The Nitecore TINI is a good idea, but very poorly executed. The small design, the big reflector, the two buttons, the nice premium metals are all welcome innovations from the company that revolutionized the keychain flashlight, but they need to listen to customers and strive for better reliability and durability.

review_title: I wanted to love this flashlight, but the interface is BIZARRE (and annoying).
reviews: I wanted to love this flashlight. It's absolutely tiny, extremely bright, rechargable (a must for me), with a pretty decent battery especially for the size - all at a great price. They've even gone back to having a dust cap over the charging port which is smart. I have numerous Nitecore flashlights and they keep getting weirder with each new iteration. Unfortunately, the interface on this little guy is bizarre and clumsy - you can't lock it in turbo mode (it's a momentary on / off switch)...you have to press the power button for a full two seconds to turn it on. That might not sound like long, but trust me - in my line of work it is INCREDIBLY annoying. I need to inspect and repair the workings of electrical / mechanical equipment in various lighting conditions all day, every day. I have been wearing keychain flashlights on a lanyard around my neck for many years. I would estimate that I have to turn on a flashlight a minimum of twenty times each day...perhaps more than a hundred on a busy day. The buttons are so close together that I keep accidentally hitting both of them at the same time while trying to turn it on which keeps switching the unit from "demo" mode to "daily" mode and back again. Because of that, I have to start over with the two-second thing each time. Rinse and repeat. So...Nitecore: um...what's the first thing someone usually does when they pick up a flashlight? Hint: the answer probably has something to do with, i donno, turning the thing on? Why the bizarre two-second delay for using a flashlight's primary function? Make it a .5 second delay AT MOST. Just strange...this is *almost* hands-down the best keychain flashlight in the world...get rid of this silly interface and you'll easily have the crown. Give me the interface from the Nitecore Tube on this flashlight, and I'd buy half a dozen of them.
